text: <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was originally identified in post-synaptic densities of excitatory synapses in the brain of rats [ 1 ] , but this protein is widely expressed in a variety of tissues [ 2 ] .

Two allelic , autosomal recessive mutations in the <extra_id_0> Sharpin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene occurred spontaneously in two inbred strains of mice , C57B / KaLawRij-Sharpincpdm / Sharpincpdm and CBy.Ocb3 / Dem-Sharpincpdm-Dem / Sharpincpdm-Dem , resulting in premature termination of mRNA synthesis and absence of a functional protein product [ 2 ] .

text: Despite different genetic backgrounds , both mutations cause similar inflammatory disease with severe chronic progressive dermatitis and defective development of secondary lymphoid organs [ 2 ] - [ 4 ] .
The dermatitis becomes clinically apparent at about four weeks of age .

There are accumulations of eosinophils , neutrophils and macrophages in the skin of Sharpincpdm / Sharpincpdm mutant mice ( hereafter referred to as cpdm mice ) associated with increased expression of Th2 cytokines in the skin and in the supernatants of activated splenocytes [ 5 ] .

The mice have an impaired delayed type hypersensitivity response and decreased secretion of <extra_id_0> IFNgamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 5 ] , indicating a defect in Th1 immune responses and a bias towards a Th2 immune response .

text: Systemic treatment of cpdm mice with recombinant IL12 caused complete remission of the dermatitis [ 5 ] .

Neutralization of <extra_id_0> IL5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by antibody treatment or crosses with <extra_id_0> IL5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient mice reduced the number of circulating and cutaneous eosinophils , but failed to reduce the onset and severity of the dermatitis [ 6 ] .

text: Recently , three independent groups identified <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as an essential component of the linear ubiquitin chain assembly complex ( LUBAC ) that regulates <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced canonical NF-kappaB signaling [ 7 ] - [ 9 ] .

<extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient mouse embryonic fibroblast ( MEF ) were sensitized to <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced apoptosis and cell death was implicated as a factor in the dermatitis of cpdm mice [ 7 ] - [ 9 ] .
Dendritic cells ( DC ) have a sentinel role in sensing pathogen or danger signals and initiate and direct activation of the adaptive immune response [ 10 ] .
Activated and mature DC can carry processed antigenic peptides , migrate to lymphoid organs , and induce T-cell - mediated immune responses or tolerance .
DC direct the differentiation of CD4+ T cells , and hence the type of immune response , through the selective secretion of cytokines .
We hypothesized that defective cytokine secretion by DC contributed to the Th2-biased inflammatory phenotype in <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient mice .

The studies reported here found that lack of <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein in BMDC caused defective expression of pro-inflammatory mediators and impaired NF-kappaB activation upon ligand stimulation .
The ability of cpdm BMDC to stimulate Th1 cytokine production in allogeneic CD4+ T cells was compromised .

Taken together , these results reveal that <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a novel regulatory molecule in DC biology and suggest that the dysregulated function of <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient DC plays a role in the cpdm phenotype .
